Award.AwardTitle: CAP: Partnerships for Indigenous Knowledge and Digital Literacies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project lays the academic foundations for collaborations between researchers and indigenous American Indian community-based language practitioners for the purpose of developing a socio-technical means of, in parallel, preserving ancient indigenous languages and traditional ecological knowledge (TEK), and helping indigenous youth learn traditional languages and knowledge. The projected plan is to engage indigenous youth in the design of augmented reality immersive experiences for others (ARGs) that incorporate social media and immerse others in the culture and languages of the community as a means towards addressing these goals. Such an approach places youth in the position of being producers of immersive experiences for others and active collaborators with elders who they can share with and learn from. During the course of this Cyberlearning Capacity-Building Project (CAP), the PIs are convening a set of workshops involving researchers, indigenous language practitioners, and indigenous elders and youth to lay the foundations for later collaborative research and planning. Indigenous participants are being introduced to what is known about how people learn and about designing experiences for promoting learning; researchers are being introduced to the resources, needs, and knowledge of the indigenous people. American Indian participants are from four separate but linguistically-related tribal communities in the Midwest.

The next generation of indigenous peoples is faced with an awesome burden: how to sustain local ecosystems, languages, and lands in the face of rampant language, culture, and policy shifts. Existing theories of language and learning do not address these issues, and project participants are laying the groundwork for both developing theory around indigenous language and cultural learning and exploring the roles technology might play in drawing youth into these activities and helping them learn and preserve traditional languages and culture. Finding new channels for the transmission of indigenous languages and traditional ecological knowledge is both a practical and intellectual enterprise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Partnerships in Indigenous Knowledge and Digital Literacies project aimed to develop projects involving augmented reality mobile indigenous language learning (ARMILL) digital games and applications, where the indigenous participants were the producers and were provided the means to create pedagogical tools in ways consistent with their linguistic, cultural and educational needs and to build capacity for community engagement with both the academic team and with each other beyond the scope of this project.

Outcomes: The key project activities occurred during a range of ARMILL game development workshops for building capacity for participants from Ft. Mojave and several other indigenous groups—Hualapai, Maricopa, Mojave (Mohave) from the Colorado River Tribes Reservation, and Tohono O’dham—held in June 2014, June 2015, and June 2016 and during a site visit in February 2015 to Aha Macav charter school in Ft. Mojave to work with teachers in their own classroom/school context. A variety of complementary symposia, talks, and sponsored workshops were also held between from November 2013 and June 2016. The project has resulted in the creation of a permanent website (http://indigenousdiglit.wordpress.com) that is accessible to individuals interested in the project into the future, with reference to two demonstration games and self-study materials for developing ARMILL games, independently (Several ARMILL digital games were produced during the project period and remain the property of the creators). The project also sponsored scholarships for indigenous educators to participate in AILDI (http://aildi.arizona.edu) workshops for technology-enhanced indigenous language documentation, revitalization and learning and the project has been presented and shared at several institute and conference talks.

Intellectual Merit: The key intellectual questions addressed through this project were, how does the new technology of ARMILL digital games would help meet the education needs of small, rural indigenous communities? What issues are involved in training participants in this new technology? How do community members choose to adapt such technology to meet their language and culture needs? Is it useful to build capacity of participants from small, rural communities in this type of technology and to what degree can developed games be shared across communities?  In these locations, there is a general absence of supportive technology which might be used to raise technological skills while providing support for their highly endangered languages and cultures. The technology employed allows for the creation of educational materials in the indigenous languages themselves and with content appropriate for each community. There is a strong desire in targeted small communities to take steps to preserve their highly endangered languages and cultures. Opportunities to pass on linguistic and cultural knowledge in the traditional ways have been unavailable due to the lack of fluent speakers or of a pool of elders who are able to teach. Creating ARMILL digital games presents an interesting opportunity for the intergenerational transmission of indigenous knowledge through technology. Grandparents, children and their teachers can co-construct and use digital games using the technology developed.

Broader Impacts: The outcomes served to build a stronger relationship between the smaller tribal communities and the university-based researchers so that new avenues for collaboration and support were established. The linguistic similarity between most of the tribal communities involved ensures the opportunity to share the constructed games. The model has also been shared in a variety of workshops with many other tribal communities through the project’s collaboration with the American Indian Language Development Institute (AILDI) who hosted several workshops. Trainings included community-based teachers and some high school students, fostering the ability of the students, as well as the teachers, to construct ARMILL games for use in educational environments. The content of ARMILL games allows the creators to lean heavily on cultural and linguistic information that supports the community need to preserve their highly endangered languages and cultures. As a result of the workshops and symposia, participants were able to construct their own game, in their own language, with their own cultural content. Integrating such tools into mainstream schooling is an important bridge in these small communities between traditional knowledge and modern western pedagogy. As well, the engagement of different age groups in this learning process encouraged intergenerational transmission of both language and culture.

We believe that being able to experience and learn one’s heritage language as an object of modern technology mediation is empowering and effective, especially to Indigenous youth, who may normally experience their heritage language only as something spoken by elders or for ceremonial purposes. We think that by experiencing and learning their heritage language in this way, youth might be more likely to take ownership of their heritage and see the personal value in learning their heritage language.
